thread.title: Appalachian heritage thrives in the Smokies
thread.title_full: Appalachian heritage thrives in the Smokies

author: Anita Wadhwani, USA TODAY
title: Appalachian heritage thrives in the Smokies
text:
Fall is here, and Cades Cove at the foot of the Great Smoky Mountains has come alive. GreenStock, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The colors throughout the mountains are spectacular, and make for perfect sightseeing. Muhur, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The sun rises over Foothills Parkway West in the Great Smoky Mountains of Tennessee, bringing to life the colors of fall. GreenStock, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen As America’s most-visited national park, Great Smoky Mountains National Park offers the most bio-diverse land on the continent. NPS.gov Fullscreen The park was saved from logging companies in the 1930s by an odd coalition, including... Eileen Blass USAT Fullscreen Tennessee and North Carolina conservationists, landowners who donated their land, and theAmerican Auto Club (AAA). National Park Service Fullscreen The park offers a beloved escape for city dwellers and a critical habitat for thousands of plant and animal species. Eileen Blass USAT Fullscreen It also preserves remnants of the cultural history of the Cherokee people. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Cherokee once inhabited a portion of these lands before they were driven westward on the Trail of Tears. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Appalachian Trail traverses the park from west to east, and is one of the iconic features of the park. National Park Service Fullscreen Haze shrouds hills in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park as seen at Newfound Gap. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Reduced visibility caused by poor air quality is one of the environmental pressures on the park. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Though the name Smoky came about due to natural fogs given off by the vegetation. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen At an elevation of 5,046 feet, Newfound Gap offers prime stargazing on clear, moonless nights. Adam Lau AP Fullscreen Anglers will find more than 700 miles of fishable stream. National Park Service Fullscreen Those streams include some of the last wild trout streams in the Eastern United States. National Park Service Fullscreen Larger streams are home to smallmouth bass. National Park Service Fullscreen A valid North Carolina or Tennessee fishing license is required for anglers over 16. National Park Service Fullscreen Alum Cave Creek is one of the many rivers and streams that flow in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Great Smoky Mountains National Park is laced with many rivers and streams including the Walker Camp Prong of the Little Pigeon River. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Sara Tucker, 8, and Caleb, 7, and Cavin Dixon, 3, walk behind the Grotto Falls in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Erik Plakanis, a trail guide with the company A Walk in the Woods, leads the Besecker family on a hike into the wilderness. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen The views at spots like Roaring Fork aren't so bad either. NPS.gov Fullscreen The natural beauty in the parks begs to be explored. Ann Foschauer Fullscreen And while the Blue Ridge Parkway offers great views, there's nothing like getting out into the park. National Park Service Fullscreen While the colors of the park are beautiful year round... National Park Service Fullscreen The fall might be the most striking time of year to visit. National Park Service Fullscreen The colors in the 187,000 acres of forest only add to the natural beauty. National Park Service Fullscreen The mountains come alive with a rainbow of hues. Great Smoky Mtns NP Photo Fullscreen And nothing can beat the views. National Park Service Fullscreen Winter brings its own kind of beauty to the park, as well. Tom Harrington Fullscreen National Park Service National Park Service Fullscreen A late autumn coat of ice and snow covers trees in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park near Gatlinburg, Tenn. Paul Efird AP Fullscreen Snow covers trees and vegetation along Little River Road to Cades Cove in The Great Smoky Mountains National Park near Maryville, Tenn. Tom Sherlin AP Fullscreen The park offers a number of recreational opportunities including swimming and tubing in its many rivers and streams. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Horseback riders can choose from four concession horse stables that offer guided horseback rides Adam Brimer AP Fullscreen Motorists cruise the Blue Ridge Parkway by the millions, sometimes bumper-to-bumper. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen Campers have many options for sleeping under the stars, from the solitude of the backcountry to the camaraderie of a group campsite or a drive-in campground. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen If camping isn't your thing, stay in a log lodge in the Great Smoky Mountains near Asheville. The Blackberry Suite has a private porch. Glenda Cahill Wildberry Lodge B Fullscreen A road lined with cabins zig-zags up a peak just outside of Great Smoky Mountains National Park. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen The undisputed king of Smoky Mountain wildlife is the black bear. NPS.gov Fullscreen Biologists estimate there are about 1,500 living within the park. Lisa Barger XXX Fullscreen Over 65 mammal species make the park home, including elk. National Park Service Fullscreen Deer are plentiful as well in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen They can be hard to spot because of dense foliage, but several spots offer prime viewing. National Park Service Fullscreen Your best bet is to hang out in the early morning or at dusk in open areas like Cades Cove and Cataloochee. National Park Service Fullscreen Barred Owls frequent the park, but might be difficult to see. Ann Froschauer Fullscreen Their camouflaging plumage and silent wings make them practically invisible. National Park Service Fullscreen A turkey hen roosts in a tree with her chicks. National Park Service Fullscreen And of course, there are no shortages of gray squirrels. National Park Service Fullscreen Beautiful flora like the Crimson Bee Balm can be found throughout the park. Tom Harrington Fullscreen The most-visited national park, Great Smoky Mountains might also be the most beautiful. National Park Service Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide The sun sets over Tennessee's Great Smoky Mountain National Park from the vantage point of Cliff Top near LeConte Lodge on Mount LeConte. (Photo: Joe Howell, AP)
9 CONNECT 11 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE There's music in these mountains — beyond the crash of waterfalls and the early morning choruses of the hundreds of bird species that dwell in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.
The nation's most visited national park drew more than 10 million people last year and is best known for majestic views from some of the tallest peaks in the Eastern USA, the wild elk and bears that roam the land, and the miles of hiking trails crisscrossing half a million acres straddling the North Carolina-Tennessee border.
But the park is dedicated to more than preserving and protecting its vast natural resources. A key component of the park's mission is preserving the rich and distinctively American heritage of the southern Appalachian people who lived in the mountains before it became a national park.
The park has one of the largest collections of log homes, barns, churches and schools in the East, with more than 90 buildings that have been preserved or rehabilitated. Visitors can catch a glimpse of daily life for early Appalachian settlers by strolling through mountain farm exhibits or attending one of the numerous festivals that celebrate mountain culture.
At the annual Cosby in the Park festival, visitors can experience southern Appalachian culture in music, quilting displays, corn-shuck dolls and crafts lessons, old- time toys, folk art and natural foods and medicinal plants at the park's Cosby Campground.
Junior ranger programs, offered year-round throughout the park, give children lessons in blacksmithing and milling.
Faye Sykes of Clintwood, Va., takes photographs in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. (Photo: Amy Smotherman Burgess, AP)
A Women's Work Festival at the Mountain Farm Museum honors the often arduous daily lives led by southern Appalachian women in maintaining a household, with demonstrations of folkways and homemaking chores, including open-hearth cooking, spinning and sewing at the Oconaluftee Visitor Center each June.
The Mountain Life Festival each fall at the Mountain Farm Museum gives visitors a peek into the past, when soap, apple cider, sorghum molasses and hominy were made by hand.
Music serves as the touchstone for many of the park's cultural heritage events. One of the biggest celebrations of Appalachian musical events in the country takes place each September at the Sugarlands Visitors Center.
The Great Smoky Mountains Institute at Tremont offers living history workshops and programs for children and adults on mountain music and the rich traditions of the southern Appalachian people. The University of Tennessee offers visitors classes in the park on history and culture, too.
The park also has ongoing efforts to ensure that descendants of families that settled the area have the ability to visit old home places and cemeteries, and hold annual reunions, says park spokeswoman Dana Soehn.
Haze shrouds the ridges above Cades Cove, a broad, green valley that's among the most popular destinations in the park. (Photo: H. Darr Beiser, USA Today)
On a recent day at the Oconaluftee Visitor Center, nestled in the foothills of the mountains on the North Carolina side of the park, 66-year-old Randy Jones sat on the porch with a dozen other amateur musicians and struck up the twangy sounds of songs such as Home Sweet Home and Red River Valley.
As hikers, mountain bikers and others gathered to listen to the old-time mountain music — music with roots in the hardscrabble daily lives of the park's early settlers — Jones invited them to get carried away. "Clap, hoot and holler," he said, "whatever the spirit leads you to do."
Wadhwani also reports for The Tennessean of Nashville.
The Middle Prong of the Little River rushes past snow-covered banks in Great Smoky Mountains National Park last winter. (Photo: Mark A. Large, AP)
About the park
Size : 521,086 acres
Visitors : 10,099,276 in 2014
Established : 1934
History : The park was established in part because loggers were rapidly cutting the primeval forests that remained. More than 1,200 residents had to leave their land once the park opened.
When visiting : The park has four visitor centers: the Cades Cove center near Townsend, Tenn.; the Oconaluftee center on U.S. 441, 2 miles north of Cherokee, N.C.; the Sugarland center 2 miles south of Gatlinburg, Tenn. on U.S. 441; and the Clingmans Dome center 7 miles off U.S. 441 in Tennessee. Visitor information: 865-436-1200.
Of note : The park is among the most biologically diverse areas in the eastern USA, with more than 17,000 species of plants, animals and invertebrates, but scientists believe an additional 30,000 to 80,000 species may live there.
To learn about park sites from all 50 states, order USA TODAY’s special edition, National Treasures at onlinestore.usatoday.com. (Photo: USA Today)
